question: Which resource, when used, causes air pollution?

content.source_1: Burning coal releases large amounts of air pollutants—such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter—and carbon dioxide, making coal combustion a major cause of air pollution.
content.source_2: Using coal for energy typically involves burning it to produce heat or electricity.
content.source_3: Compared per unit of useful energy produced, coal combustion emits more CO2 and conventional air pollutants than burning oil or natural gas.
content.source_4: Peat used as a fuel has a higher carbon intensity than coal; per unit of energy released, burning peat emits even more CO2 and also produces substantial particulate and other air pollutants.
content.source_5: When peat is used as an energy resource, it is burned in stoves or power plants to generate heat and electricity.
content.source_6: Per unit of energy delivered, petroleum fuels such as gasoline and diesel emit less CO2 when burned than coal.
